Claim: People should not follow any specific religion.
The religion (if any) that lets them be happiest w/o being immoral

This assumes a moral system independent of religion, that says happiness is good and can judge whether people are immoral. Such a position is difficult to specify without some religious claims, e.g. "morality stems from God" vs "morality is independent of God".
Religion has had a net negative impact on humanity.
Religious institutions enable child abuse.
Homophobia is largely the product of religious bigotry worldwide.
Religion has slowed technological progress for all mankind.
Religion makes people sexist.
Many of the teachings of the Bible are damaging to women.
The Bible teaches that women on their period are unclean and should be ostracised.
In this verse "unclean" is meant in a ceremonial sense and doesn't have moral implications.
Similar standards are applied to men. For instance, when a man has an "emission of semen" he is also unclean (Leviticus 15:16).
In general, religious people seem to function in society at least as good as non-religious people.
One might follow any particular religion and achieve the same benefits, given that their teachings point to the same fundamental source, however slight the difference in terminology may be.
Religion at its purest state is a transcendent endeavor which, in many different ways, gives a sense of purpose and meaning to the individual.

Nobody can honestly declare that they know what the "purest state" of all religions is. There are too many of them, and they are too diverse, not to mention that most of them are lost to history, so we can't even evaluate how they fit into this particular mold.
All religions which stress a connection with the spiritual world will, if fully comprehended, be beneficial to the individual.
According to the Bahá'í faith the major religions are fundamentally unified in purpose, though varied in social practices and interpretations.
Religions are dogmatic that makes them conservative and unable to keep with progressing civilisation. Religious "truths" are often outdated.
Many religions promote a patriarchal view of the world that is incompatible with the equality agenda of many modern societies.
Facts do not become outdated. If God does or does not exist, the same was true 10,000 years ago, and remains unimpacted by human progress.
It is very unlikely that any god or gods that came to Earth would resemble the gods depicted in our religions.
Gods are defined by religion. To say that religions incorrectly describe what gods are really like, is like saying that fantasy fiction incorrectly describes what dragons are really like.
Each person is different and each of us need a different mindset and belief system to cope with reality.

People of integrity will figure out what they believe, and call it by the most accurately descriptive name they can think of. If there are no others in the same category, that should not be allowed to influence what they believe.
Having false beliefs about reality is itself a failure to cope with reality. One should choose what to believe based on what is true, not based on what is most pleasant to believe.
People are only different to the extent that their beliefs are different.
Since reality is the same, the beliefs should also be the same.
People should act based on reason, not beliefs.
Colonialization was exacerbated by religion. en.wikipedia.org chronicle.co.zw
Kialo discurssion:     Morality precedes religion. Therefore, religion is not necessary for determining right from wrong.
Religion can cause mental trauma in children. Religious abuse against children
Belief systems can cause the persecution of innocents. E.g. Persecution of people with albinism
Belief systems can be a threat to health. E.g.Anti-vaccination movement or Condom controversy
The rationale for morality seems lacking in a system with no authority or objective standard.
If there is no ultimate being that defines morality then there is no meaning to moral actions, no source or rationale that grounds goodness or badness.

There is no property of 'ultimate' that imbues meaning, nor is there any indication that a lack of 'ultimate' is incapable of assigning meaning or value to actions. This is a theological talking point that is entirely unsupported by anything.

To base personal morality on the demands of an authority figure REMOVES all meaning from moral actions. If one does not murder because it will cause pain to that persons family and friends, or because they will feel bad about terminating the life of a potentially valuable member of society, that has social and personal meaning. If one does not murder because it is against the rules, that is simply a fear-based action with no perspective, and is devoid of meaning.

If some "ultimate being" claims to define morality, their definition is merely that being's subjective opinion. Whether the "ultimate being" in question is a delusional autocrat or some entity with real magic powers makes no difference to that fact.
Atheism has poorer explanations about many important aspects of life, including morality and beauty, than theism.

There is no empirical means of determining morality without first adding an un-empirical assertion. Therefore, either the un-scientific religion of philosophy or another religion must be employed to provide these un-empirical assertions.
Religion provides a unified standard basis for ethical consideration.
Kialo discurssion:     We need religion for morality.
Even if it is unified, it has numerous other deficiencies that make it unacceptable as a basis for morality.
Atheism makes no claims on morality.
Atheism claims that truth is better than falsehood, or else it wouldn’t argue that the idea of God is false.
But the same reasoning, any claim (to claim something is the same as claiming it is true) whatsoever would be implicitly a claim that truth is better than falsehood.
Atheism per se does not claim or entail this.

Atheism at its core is simply the claim that God does not exist - not any arguments atheists may make for the truth of that claim. Hence, it does not argue that He does not exist, and more generally does not claim that truth is better than falsehood.
Implicit in the act of making a claim, which is "to assert as a fact," is the assumption that truth (the fact) is better than falsehood.
A fact can be defined as "truth".
This would imply that the statement "falsehood is better than truth" is logically incoherent, yet it appears to be a meaningful claim.

Certainly, saying “falsehood is better than truth” is a self-refuting claim if not expounded on. By itself, it asserts to say something true while denying truth. It is therefore devoid of meaning. It is like saying “words do not exist”.

Someone might also say “truth is no better than falsehood”. They would be claiming meaninglessness, as it would be no better to know or say something true or false. And their statement would therefore lack meaning, since everything lacks meaning.

Someone could say “deceiving your enemy is better than revealing the truth”. Or “it is more helpful to withhold the truth from that stressed-out person at this time”. But both of those statements acknowledge truth in general- they assert that some truths (beating the enemy or minimizing anxiety) are very important.

Someone could say “being so concerned with finding the truth about *a given topic* (such as someone’s true opinion about you) is unhelpful”. But this statement doesn't deny the existence of truth and the overall benefit of knowing and speaking truth about most things like the blanket statement “falsehood is better than truth”. The former statement actually admits some beneficial truth: namely that being obsessed over something minor is unhealthy.

Anyone who believed "falsehood is better than truth" would not believe it if it were true, as they would consider falsehoods better (and hence preferable) to truths. Thus, it it were true and they believed it, they would be led to reject it.

If falsehood were indeed better than truth, then claiming "falsehood is better than truth" would be a true claim, although it might thereby be a "bad" claim by whatever measure of better/worse is meant. Hence, it is meaningful and not self-refuting.
Kialo discurssion:     Morality is objective.

One atheistic view of morality is that it is an evolved social construct. As such, it is liable to change, perhaps even disappear. Many theistic views of morality, such as Christianity's teachings of love, are profound enough to be flexible for cultural differences, but are rooted in an unchanging and objective source - God, and are not at risk of fading away.

This argument assumes that the existence of morality in itself has value. As a human social construct, morality would not exist without humans. Under such circumstances, it would be meaningless to ascribe any negative value to its absence.

If God does not in fact exist, then theistic views of morality are not rooted in an unchanging and objective source, but a fictional character. As such, they would be at least as likely of changing or disappearing, but would not have any explanation for how or why that could happen, making them worse explanations for morality.
Seeking explanation through evidence, even if we have not discovered the explanation yet, is not a poorer explanation than making something up when you have no evidence.

This is begging the question, because if God does not exist, which is atheism's central claim, then theistic explanations of morality and beauty are resting on a false premise and are very poor if not completely invalid.

The following, while oversimplified, is not begging the question: If there is moral objectivity, then there is a God. Universally, people get upset at unfairness, especially upon themselves, but also often when they see it happen to others. It seems like there is some moral objectivity. There likely is a God.

If a more comprehensive argument for objective morality is made, then a logical argument using objective morality as proof for theism becomes powerful, so long as many of the arguments for objective morality appeal to evidence and not the concept of a god.
The fact that there are some 4000 religions in the world with differing claims on morality would be evidence that there is no such thing as objective morality.

Asserting that there’s no objective morality because there are many religions is like saying “the fact that there are many claims on what is true about cosmological origins must mean that objective truth does not exist”. Since objective truth is being assumed, that particular argument against objective morality may not, on its own, be conclusive.
The reason for atheism is not to give simple answers to all questions, but to get rid of false answers.
Theism's answers are not simple within its own framework. If God created everything, then the reason (God) is greater than those seeking the answers (people).
For atheism to get rid of false answers, theism must be proven false. Theism has not been proven to be false.
There are other methods of getting rid of false answers. Scientism, naturalism, materialism offer an actual framework. Atheism is merely a disbelief. It is not specific enough.
Materialism cannot deal with answers to questions as consciousness is required to ask questions.

Atheism, the lack of a belief in a deity, does not attempt to explain aspects of life other than if there is sufficient evidence to believe in a deity. This is akin to saying that Christianity has a poor explanation for how programming works.
There is a moral component to insisting that people not believe if there is insufficient evidence. Because of this, atheism must deal with morality.
Saying you shouldn't believe something without reasonable evidence does not contain any moral component. It is about logic. It is not about right and wrong, it is about reasonableness.

"Evidence" is a description, and can be objective. "Shouldn't" and "Reasonable" are value judgments, and subjective based on one's biases. Thus, while it's fair to say that the act of believing something or not has no moral component, to say that someone "shouldn't" believe something without "reasonable" evidence is a moral imperative.

Humans tend to behave irrationally until educated, and it takes a lot of education to think rationally on a consistent basis. It may even be unfeasible. Asking people to train themselves for rational thinking on origins seems to have moral implications.
Truth vs a lie is a moral issue. People can arguably be just as happy not knowing the truth. We ask each other to care about the truth because lies are somehow wrong.
Without an agreed upon system of morality, humans won’t be able to solve moral disputes, which is problematic when trying to create a functional society.
The fallibility of human beings will cause people to pick and choose what may ultimately be evil and wrong rather than what is true about the religion.
It is impossible to choose one's morality as choice implies values and thus choice presupposes some value system.

Tailoring our beliefs until we agree with everything ignores the possibility of a higher Being that has a unique way of thinking. We cannot choose for ourselves what a God has declared moral or immoral.
There is no good reason to think a God would care how humans behaved, assuming a God existed.

If God existed and created us, he probably created us because he was trying to fulfill some sort of goal that the existence of humanity can help achieve. If there is anything at all we can do to help fulfill this goal of God's then God would care that we do it.
There is no good reason to think humans were specially created by any divinely guided or caused act or process.
The only way it would matter what God considered moral and immoral is if he rewarded and punished based on behavior, in which case we should care purely out of self interest.
Moral disputes are better left in the hands of being solved by rationality and compassion than the presupposition of ancient books that cannot feasibly argue their morality in a modern world.
Compassion is not an effective way of solving moral disputes because the sides will likely disagree over which view is most "compassionate."
Moral disputes can be resolved by appealing to common values. If there are no relevant common values, the dispute is likely not even possibly settled.

Given that there is no one universally accepted 'true' religion, this is already the case, and thus it is better to consider one's beliefs within the concept of rationality and reason rather than to wait until one emerges as the universally 'true' religion.

Morality is not associated exclusively to religious beliefs. For example, the belief that we should not murder another person does not need moral backing for it to be associated with a positive moral decision.
This assumes that the purpose of religion is to facilitate human societal flourishing in the present life.
Morality, as well as religion, arises from social interactions. A society can have morals but no religion. The opposite may also be true.
Humans have always lived in societies, and the rationale for morality is probably that it makes societies healthier.
Societies that have morals but no religion borrow the concept of morality from religious societies.

Religions/belief systems are not needed for morals. "Moral truths are truths of reason; that is, a moral judgment is true if it is backed by better reasons than the alternatives" (citation from The Elements of Moral Philosophy (PDF))
Moral Relativism simply allows for more diverse, rather than weaker, rationales for morality, and is often the preferred view over Moral Objectivism.
Belief systems are necessary to motivate important social change.
The civil rights movement was based on a belief that people of all races deserve equal rights.
The abolitionist movement was based on the belief that human beings should not be treated as property.
Kialo discurssion:     Religion has been a good thing for humankind.

Rationalism is held as the institutional solution to everything. Yet, those institutions act on empirical findings and social dogmas instead. No observer is at liberty to rule with findings that embrace the mind of their professors and superiors. Only supporting thought can pass as valued and valid. So much writing is then used to critique all human tendency.

"Beliefs" is hopelessly broad, and in addition to the supernatural beliefs common in religion it rules out all knowledge, as knowledge is often defined as "justified true belief". Reasoning without knowledge is ineffective at best and incoherent at worst.
People should abandon organised religion, as the spiritual path is a personal path.
Believing in aspects of different religions allows an individual to have a more personal understanding of their place in the cosmos.
One should not choose beliefs for whether they offer a "more personal understanding", but for whether those beliefs are true.
A personal understanding may or may not be actually true.
A personal path is still a "set of beliefs." A personal philosophy, or "religion," is ultimately unavoidable.
A person's personal spiritual path oftentimes leads them directly into an organized religion.
While a spiritual path truly is a personal path, organized religion helps us know which paths to walk and provide a support group that encourages us to endure.

To go deep spiritually often requires embracing apparent paradox. An effective spiritual practice is indeed about the growth of the individual, but it is from within a supportive spiritually mature community that true individuals are most likely to emerge.
Beliefs should be based on verifiable evidence. A religion is a collection of multiple sets of beliefs which may or may not be true depending on their supporting evidence.
Belief is defined as 'the feeling of being certain that something exists or is true,' and thus is based on a feeling rather than necessarily on evidence.
Human beliefs may well be based more on feelings than on rational assessment of the available evidence, but that is a human failing, not an indication of what beliefs should be based on.
Belief is not based on evidence. Science is.
Kialo discurssion:     Religious faith and science are not mutually exclusive.

Religions are interconnected systems of beliefs, not mere "collections" or "sets". As the beliefs are not independent, one should assess the validity of the central claims of a religion and reject those which are false rather than waste time on every individual point.
This belief is itself not based on verifiable evidence. Some beliefs are by necessity axiomatic.

Religion is a right people should be allowed to practice, yet it would be more beneficial to follow no religion, so that we as humans may develop our own moral, and philosophical ideas unencumbered by religious obligations, and convictions.
It is statistically unlikely that all of the claims of a single religion are true, and far more likely that true claims are scattered across different religions.
A religion created by humans will have human limitations. So that religion cannot have the truth. It would have a piece of truth.
If someone creates a religion, that person won't have all the knowledge to have the truth for everything. That's a limitation. So that religion hasn't the absolute truth.
Religions are often based on the circumstances in which a community lives in rather than on objective truth.
The religion of the ancient Romans developed due to the influence of Greek religions.
A true religion would be created by God or the gods, not by humans, and with divine assistance a true prophet could presumably communicate the entire truth and overcome mortal limitations.

A religion created by humans without divine intervention or assistance is, at least if it has prophets who claim to know things about the gods, a false religion created by liars or madmen. Any truth it has will be by accident, and that truth will be better found elsewhere.
Religions could each be correct on some tenets but not all. Thus possibly there is no "best" religion, but only maybe "best practices" individually from each religion.
Many religions are already influenced by others.
Many religions specifically cannot be followed only in part. To follow in part is not to follow it at all.
If this is true, then only the strictest fundamentalists could be considered true followers of any faith.

If a religion bases its tenets on their god's commands, and their god does not exist, then all of its tenets are false. This limits how many and which religions can even potentially be "correct on some tenets but not all".
Some tenets could be correct by chance alone, although the tenets of a false religion will not be reliably correct.
Many religions explicitly state that other religions are not true. It is contradictory to claim that they can all be true when some cannot coexist with others.
Universalism is expressly rejected by Jesus himself. John 14:6 (ESV): "Jesus said to him, 'I am the way, and the truth, and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me.'"
If the ultimate goal is to reach the highest exaltation and Jesus says it is only by him, he is saying that taking a different path will not lead you there.
If understood that Jesus was speaking for God and not for himself, then there is no contradiction.
Jesus would certainly say that some religions are more correct than others as is evidenced by his conversation with the Samaritan woman at the well. (John 4:1-26)
Something being correct is binary. It does not make sense to say something is "more correct" if it is still incorrect.
In human understanding many things can be more correct.

If someone dies, and I ask you why it happened, and I tell you it was because of brain trauma that might be correct, but if the person was killed because someone hit him on the head, then it would be more correct for me to say that he was murdered.

If a man loves his wife and someone asks him how he feels about her, and he says, "I like her a lot." That is correct, but it would be more correct for him to say he loves her. Both statements are true, but one expresses what is more correct.
This conversation (John 4:1-26) makes no reference to the correctness of other religions.

The conversation with the woman at the well absolutely discusses the correctness of religion. Paraphrasing: The Samaritans worship incorrectly ("They worship what they do not know") while the Jews worship correctly ("They worship what they do know"), but they are both incorrect because they should be worshipping in spirit and in truth.
A person does not need to know Jesus to follow him. See Romans 2:13-15
If the religions weren't true in any point nobody would follow their ideas. All of them have some point that is true.
Mathematically, it isn't possible to predict the location of another point on a scatterplot by knowing only that one spot is correct.
Religious claims such as "God exists" and "Jesus is the son of God" are more related to each other than mere points on a scatterplot.

Limiting the amount of information available to reach conclusions is not advisable when trying to ascertain truth, certainty or just the ability to make more informed decisions. There is an unbelievably large amount of information about spirituality spread across continents and cultures and throughout history. Evaluating as much information as possible is far better than limiting yourself to one source, usually one in line with where you were born and who you were born to.
Assuming spirituality is a reality and not just a part of the human condition, taking in as many spiritual sources in forming your worldview is more valuable than limiting it to a select few.

Taking in information from many different religions is not inconsistent with making an informed decision on which faith is the One True Faith, or with making an informed judgement that all religions are false and one should be an atheist.
The likelihood of any claim is relative to the evidence for it. If there is evidence for a particular religion being true then this increases the likelihood of any of its claims being true.
Truth cannot be known of the supernatural, only assumed; believers tend to use the word 'faith' because of this.

This argument assumes what it is trying to prove. I.e. There is no higher intelligence that has revealed to mankind a true religion. If there is a revealed religion among the mix, then tools like statistical likelihood are irrelevant.

If God did indeed send guidance then the Truth would be universal. There should be a core fundamental belief that runs through them all. Similarly, morals/ethics would be “universal” such that vices and virtues would be clear. Only the etiquettes and laws would change from time to time, place to place, people to people or culture to culture. If it is Truth then it should not change.

The supernatural cannot be known, its truth cannot be verified and there is no reason to believe one way or another whether any information coming from a supernatural source is universal or good or true.
Just because something cannot be verified does not mean it is not true.

Unverifiable things can be known. A person can know that someone said something to them in private that the other denies. The person knows what was said even if it isn’t verifiable. There are likely many many other examples.

The problem is adding supernatural elements. If someone told you they took acid and spoke with God, you wouldn't take them very seriously because their perception of reality was altered. Acknowledging that something can alter your perception of reality makes any conclusions dubious.
If such a thing as omnipotent supernatural beings can be real then there is no reality where your senses or your opinions or your ideas can ever be known to be true.

It does mean that it cannot be shown to be true though which is important for discerning reality and evaluating things like theism or other supernatural concepts. Most theistic propositions are exclusive meaning many theists agree that most supernatural claims are necessarily false.
If no God was revealing His one true faith, then it would be far more likely atheism was true than some scattered mix of religious traditions across the globe.

Supernatural concepts have equal likelihood of being correct as there is no possible way to measure the veracity of any of them. One God or many, speaking truth or lies, with a good intention or not, all of these concepts can only ever be assumed to be true or admitted to be unknowable.
Hypotheses involving ontologically basic mental entities are no more inherently unmeasurable or unknowable than any other hypotheses.
As no ontologically basic mental entities have ever been measured or known, it impossible to make the above statement with any confidence.
That an object or phenomenon meeting a description is not thereby necessarily unmeasurable or unknowable is an a priori truth. Empirical confirmation is not needed.
The likelihood of a teaching being true isn't based on statistical probability, it's based on the teacher's degree of insight into the nature of reality.
This is not possible, since the teachings of all major religions contradict each other. You can't have multiple conflicting things be true at once.

Jesus cannot both be God, as Christians believe, and at the same time not be God, as non-Christians believe. That is basic logic. Therefore, if any one of the world religions teaches the truth, the others must, by default, be false.

Your beliefs are largely determined by your answer to the classic philosophical question "What is reality?" We should answer this question before we can hope to agree upon which religion or belief system is best.

Metaphysical ideas must complete thoughts related to Ethics, Politics, Aesthetics, or Epistemology, before anyone will consider them to be moral absolutes. No one has yet made claims such as "monism," "dualism," "theism," or "idealism" in the scope of this debate. If "God exists," no one is saying it straight to you. Not yet.

Generally speaking, our beliefs are largely determined by where we are born and raised, or perhaps in more insulated communities, where our ancestors were born and raised. Hence, for the vast majority of us, we are told what our beliefs are...we don't decide for ourselves in any meaningful way. Our beliefs are not the result of some sort of epistemologically pure search for the truth, far from it.

It doesn't matter what most people do. What matters is what people should do. Just because most people make little effort to search for the objective truth doesn't mean that the truth doesn't exist. Therefore, people should seek out the truth.

That all religions are correct together or that one may be correct serving two masters is antithetical to the purpose of this debate.  Pluralism is not faith, but a rejection of properties of the truth as moral and good.
It is very much impossible to reconcile the teachings of even the major religions, much less all of them, without major modernist/humanist reinterpretation.
Buddhism's anatta and dependent origination are incompatible with christian afterlife and eternal soul.
Polytheism and monotheism cannot be true at the same time.

Polytheism and monotheism can be simultaneously true. Monism is the concept that the various discrete deities or objects are reducible to or collectively constitute a single unified homogeneous entity. Thus, for example, Hinduism is at the same time polytheistic and monotheistic.

Rather than unifying the two, monism presents a third mutually-incompatible position, as opposed to polytheistic systems that contain no higher God, and monotheistic systems that contain no lesser gods.
Claims about the logical or rational inconsistency of spiritual concepts are of little value. The mental functions of spiritual insight and reason are fundamentally separate and distinct.
That the human brain tends to fail to use logic when it reasons about spiritual "insight", does not suggest that spiritual matters are not themselves subject to logic.
Nearly all religions ask people to be act morally and follow Golden Rule

The Golden Rule has its origins in pre-Christian civilizations. The idea dates at least to the early Confucian times (551–479 BCE) and appears in Buddhism, Hinduism, Judaism, Taoism, Zoroastrianism and Ancient Greek Philosophy.
From Buddhism: One who, while himself seeking happiness, oppresses with violence other beings who also desire happiness, will not attain happiness hereafter. — Dhammapada 10.Violence
From Hinduism: Those acts that you consider good when done to you, do those to others, none else. — Taittiriya Upanishad (Shikshavalli, Eleventh Anuvaka)
From Christianity: Do to others what you want them to do to you. This is the meaning of the law of Moses and the teaching of the prophets. — Matthew 7:12
From Judaism: What is hateful to you, do not do to your fellow: this is the whole Torah; the rest is the explanation; go and learn. — Shabbath folio:31a, Babylonian Talmud
Even if most religions ask people to act the same way their beliefs are irreconcilable
The idea that religion is primarily about belief/faith is an idea that comes from Protestantism and is not true for every religious tradition
Faith is not necessarily integral to religious belief.

Tailoring beliefs to fit your own experiences and perception of the world and of religion is not the equivalent of assuming all religions are correct or that one or two or more masters need to be served. Believing spirituality is important and some of those thoughts on spiritualism throughout history have value does not necessarily have anything to do with servitude or faith.
Many religions speak of similar issues, values, morals. With a broader perspective, these can be resolved or discussed better.
There are religious faiths that follow this belief, such as the Bahá'í Faith. This path is not opposing to the spirit of the debate.
By people tailoring their own beliefs, they are in essence declaring themselves what is true and what is not. This is a religion that puts oneself in the position of god.
This is false, as trying to find the truth and being a God are very different things. By this logic, science would be a religion, and yet it is not.

This is an Equivocation. Whatever you believe is necessarily a "religion," or at least a "philosophy" with at least one prescriber (you.) And this is exactly the point of this discussion, to "tailor beliefs" and discuss which belief is best, based on all factors. You cannot avoid prescribing to one set of beliefs. A religion can be loosely defined as "A set of beliefs."

On the contrary, the claim that irreligion is itself a religion as implied is the more accurate example of equivocation--it assumes a contrived definition of "religion" that includes any opinion of itself, which is not the standard definition.
The purpose of religion is to have people work peacefully together, and tailoring beliefs, while ethical, can prevent progress because we work against each other.

All religions have greatly different belief systems, and therefore different purposes. Therefore, the purpose of "religion" is definitely not to have people peacefully working together. One cannot group together all religions as "religion", because they are so drastically different.
Having a few coherent, orthodox faiths, makes it easier to eliminate religions, and reach the truth.
If everybody can just invent their own religion taking the best elements from all religions and adopting none of the bad elements, then such personal beliefs would become unfalsifiable.
It would require huge amounts of time and cognitive energy to pick and choose among diverse religious doctrines. It is easier and more realistic to simply pick one religion to follow.

To go deeply into spiritual practice takes time and commitment, for example learning very specific meanings of agreed terms and pursuing particular practices for long enough to accurately judge their efficacy. To dip in here and there with various traditions risks misunderstanding and shallow appreciation, and can be a form of avoidance of the commitment required to go really deep.

If one can, one should take the time to consider which religion to follow just as one takes time to pick and choose in other areas of life. It is part of the business of becoming a cultivated person - one cultivates one's choices.
People pick and choose which doctrines to follow within their chosen religion. Expanding one’s choices wouldn’t require a significantly greater expenditure of time or energy.
The ease of a choice does not mean it is the true or correct one. Thinking more about an issue often leads to a more accurate and/or compelling answer.
To settle for one religion, one has to determine which is true, and since there is no consensus in this regard, to settle for one religion prematurely is not wise.
